model.hed: The Surprising Influences Behind the Work of Two Fashion Legends
model.dek: Dana Thomas explores the varied influences of Alexander McQueen and John Galliano

items.title: dam-images-daily-2015-05-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-01.jpg
items.caption: Alexander McQueen was a great fan of the British Arts and Crafts movement of the late 19th century—in particular the work of the artist William Morris. He would visit the Morris gallery in northern London, and spend weekends at his friend and patron Isabella Blow’s country house, Hilles, which was designed by a Morris disciple. McQueen’s best friend and trusted textiles man Simon Ungless liked to riff on Morris for prints. McQueen chose one of those Ungless prints—with the Morris design dripping like runny paint—for his now-legendary “Highland Rape” collection (Fall/Winter 1995–96).
items.credit: Photo: Catwalking; Courtesy of Morris & Co.

items.title: dam-images-daily-2015-05-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-02.jpg
items.caption:
For his third collection, Spring/Summer 1986’s “Fallen Angels,” John**Galliano looked to the French Empire of the early 19th century, most notably Jacques-Louis David’s portraits of Empress Josephine. For the closing passage of the show, he doused the models, including his muse Sibylle de Saint Phalle (seen here), with water to evoke a fashion trend of that period—the wetting of gowns so they clung to the body like robes in classical Greek statues. This practice led to a deadly outbreak of pneumonia among aristocrats, which was dubbed Muslin Disease.

 Left: An 1805 portrait of Joséphine de Beauharnais by Pierre-Paul Prud'hon.
items.credit: Photo: Catwalking; Fine Art Images/Heritage Images/Getty Images

items.title: dam-images-daily-2015-05-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-03.jpg
items.caption: In May 1997, Alexander McQueen traveled to Tokyo to stage a re-creation of his debut Givenchy ready-to-wear show, and was seduced by Japan’s culture and arts. Ever after, the country’s history and decor surfaced in his work, such as the embroidered kimono coat with matching hat accented with swaying Kelly-green amaranth from his landmark “VOSS” collection, Spring/Summer 2001.
items.credit: Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Books; Courtesy of The Metropolitan Museum of Art, H. O. Havemeyer Collection, Bequest of Mrs. H. O. Havemeyer, 1929

items.title: dam-images-daily-2015-05-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-04.jpg
items.caption: Galliano has long loved all things Edwardian, particularly Giovanni Boldini’s portraits of European aristocracy, and he regularly evoked them in his work, such as his debut couture collection for Dior in January 1997.
items.credit: Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Books; Wikiart

items.title: dam-images-daily-2015-05-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-alexander-mcqueen-john-galliano-inspirations-05.jpg
items.caption: For his final collection, Fall/Winter 2010–11’s “Angels and Demons,” McQueen turned to 15th-century sacred paintings, in particular German artist Stefan Lochner’s *Altarpiece of the Patron Saints of Cologne.*McQueen wanted to capture the golden, halolike light and the mysticism of the artworks in his new designs. He had completed only 80 percent of the collection when he took his own life in February 2010. When his former assistant Sebastian Pons saw the collection in the studio a few days after McQueen’s death, he gasped, “Oh my God. It’s a requiem.”
items.credit: Photo: Chris Moore/Catwalking/Getty Images; Wikimedia Commons
